title: Newton St Loe Walks

images.title: Rick Crowley / Castle Keep in Newton St. Loe College
images.caption: Castle Keep in Newton St. Loe College. Reputed to be Norman, and thought to be part of a one time fortified Manor House.

images.title: Maurice Pullin, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Field near Newton St. Loe. Haycombe Farm is almost at the centre of the frame with Haycombe Crematorium up the hill to the left.

images.title: Chris Downer / Newton St. Loe: village centre
images.caption: Village centre. The picturesque centre of this peaceful village, with small green and village shop.

images.title: Rick Crowley / Northern Lake in Newton St.Loe College
images.caption: Northern Lake in Newton St.Loe College

images.title: Maurice Pullin, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Newton Park College Taken from the lane between Wilmington and Newton St. Loe

images.title: Sharon Loxton / Newton Brook
images.caption: The Newton Brook flows north until it joins the river Avon west of Bath. Here the brook flows under the road from Newton St Loe to Odd down on the south west of Bath.

images.title: wayne tucker / Newton Park Upper Lake
images.caption: Newton Park Upper Lake

images.title: Sharon Loxton / The top of Stantonbury Hill
images.caption: The top of Stantonbury Hill. The Wansdyke passes over Stantonbury Hill, and it is also the site of an Iron age hill fort.

description: This delightful village near Bath is a fine place for a stroll with thatched cottages, a historic landscaped park and a pretty village green. This circular walk from the village visits Newton Park before climbing to Stantonbury Hill to the west. The grounds of the college are a lovely place for a walk with landscaped gardens and picturesque lakes to see. The walk starts in the village and follows footpaths south west to Newton Park and the College. The Park is an 18th-century landscaped garden, designed by the famous landscape gardener Capability Brown. The western side of the site includes Corston Brook where there are a series of prettty weirs. You'll also pass the Grade II listed Newton Park House which was built in 1762. The route continues to the neighbouring village of Stanton Prior before turning north west to climb to Stantonbury Hill where there is an iron age hillfort. You then descend the hill and follow country lane and other trails east, passing along the other side of the park. There's nice views of the park's lakes as you return to Newton St Loe.
